It was probably recorded as 27 December 1897 in the registry and the "2" was eroded. Ponticelli's mother remembered giving birth on 24 December (Christmas Eve) and that a snowstorm delayed any exit from the house for three days.{{cite news|first=Jean-Dominique|last=Merchet|title=Un "rital" qui s'est battu dans deux armées|url=http://www.liberation.fr/grand-angle/010173324-un-rital-qui-s-est-battu-dans-deux-armees|work=[[Libération]]|language=French|date=5 February 2008|accessdate=28 March 2008}}}} |death_date= {{death date|df=yes|2008|03|12|}}

''[[Légion d'honneur]]''
''[[Order of Vittorio Veneto|Ordine di Vittorio Veneto]]''{{cite news|first=Douglas|last=Martin|date=13 March 2008|title=Lazare Ponticelli, France's Last Veteran of World War I, Is Dead at 110|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/13/world/europe/13ponticelli.html?ex=1363060800&en=912ab323b3eb73e9&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss|work=The New York Times|accessdate=17 March 2008}} |laterwork= Piping and metal work}} '''Lazare Ponticelli''' (born Lazzaro Ponticelli, 24 December 1897, later mistranscribed as 7 December – 12 March 2008), [[Order of Vittorio Veneto|Knight of Vittorio Veneto]], was at 110, the last surviving officially recognized veteran of the [[First World War]] from France and the last ''[[poilu]]'' of its trenches to die.{{efn|In June 2008, three months after Ponticelli's death, [[Fernand Goux]] was discovered to be a French veteran. However, Goux was not officially recognized as a [[poilu]], or foot soldier, even though he was called up for service on 19 April, since he was only in the trenches from 3 November 1918 to the signing of the [[armistice]] on 11 November 1918.{{cite news|url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2008/06/19/460271-Le-dernier-Poilu-de-14-18-n-est-pas-mort.html|title=Le dernier Poilu de 14–18 n'est pas mort|date=19 June 2008|work=Ladepeche.fr|language=French|accessdate=3 September 2008}} Pierre Picault survived Goux by less than two weeks, but himself was an artilleryman who served less than three months, and is likewise not recognized by the French government as an "official" WWI veteran.}} Born in Italy, he travelled on his own to France at the age of eight. Aged 16, he lied about his age in order to join the [[French Army]] at the start of the war in 1914, before being transferred against his will to the [[Royal Italian Army|Italian Army]] the following year. After the war, he and his brothers founded the piping and metal work company ''Ponticelli Frères'' (Ponticelli Brothers), which produced supplies for the [[Second World War]] effort and as of 2009 was still in business. Ponticelli was the oldest living man of Italian birth and the oldest man living in France at the time of his death. Every [[Armistice Day]] until 2007 he attended ceremonies honoring deceased veterans. In his later years, he criticized war, and stored his awards from the First World War in a shoe box. While he felt unworthy of the state funeral the French government offered him, he eventually accepted one. However, he asked that the procession emphasise the common soldiers who died on the battlefield. French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] honored his wish and dedicated a plaque to them at the procession. ==Early life== Born as '''Lazzaro Ponticelli''' in Groppo Ducale, a [[frazione]] (civil parish) in [[Bettola]], [[province of Piacenza|Piacenza, Emilia-Romagna]], in northern Italy,{{cite news|date=13 March 2008|title=Lazare Ponticelli: Veteran who fought for France and Italy in the First World War|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3540707.ece|work=The Times|accessdate=16 March 2008}} he was raised in the mountain [[Hamlet (place)|hamlet]] of I Cordani, one of seven children born to Jean and Philomène Ponticelli. His father sold livestock on the fairgrounds and occasionally worked as a carpenter and cobbler.{{cite news|first=Boris|last=Thiolay|date=12 March 2008|title=Le der des ders|url=http://www.lexpress.fr/info/france/dossier/guerre1418/dossier.asp?ida=464772|work=[[L'Express (France)|L'Express]]|language=French|accessdate=26 March 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080128145244/http://www.lexpress.fr/info/france/dossier/guerre1418/dossier.asp?ida=464772|archivedate=28 January 2008|deadurl=yes}} His mother cultivated the family's small plot of land and, like many women of the area, commuted three times a year to the [[Po Valley]] to work in its rice fields. Despite the Ponticelli family's hard work, they were impoverished and the children often went to bed on an empty stomach.{{cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/lefigaromagazine/2008/01/26/01006-20080126ARTFIG00634-lazare-le-dernier-des-poilus.php|title=Lazare, le dernier des poilus|last=Hofstein|first=Cyril|date=29 January 2008|work=Le Figaro|accessdate=12 December 2008}} When Lazare was two years of age, his mother moved to France to earn a better living. After the unexpected deaths of Jean Ponticelli and his eldest son, Pierre, the rest of the family moved to Paris, leaving Lazare in the care of neighbors. At age six, Ponticelli started several jobs, including making clogs.{{cite news|language=French|first=Alain|last=Vincenot|date=13 March 2008|title=Lazare Ponticelli — C'était le dernier poilu|url=http://archive.francesoir.fr/actualite/societe/lazare-ponticelli-c’etait-dernier-poilu-24629.html|work=[[France Soir]]|accessdate=28 March 2008}} By 1906, aged eight years old, he had saved enough money to buy a railway ticket to Paris, which he considered "paradise." To travel to the capital of France, he walked {{convert|21|mi|km|0}} to the nearest train station at [[Piacenza]].{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-03-12-1835095907_x.htm|title=Last French WWI Veteran Dies|last=Pirot|first=Laurent|date=12 March 2008|agency=Associated Press|work=USA Today|accessdate=21 October 2011}} He could not speak French, but found work as a chimney sweep in [[Nogent-sur-Marne]] and later as a [[paper boy]] in Paris.{{cite news|date=12 March 2008|title=France's final WWI veteran dies|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7292109.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=12 March 2008}}{{cite news|first=James|last=Kantner|date=12 March 2008|title= Lazare Ponticelli, 110, last 'poilu' of World War I trenches|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/03/12/europe/veteran.php|work=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=17 March 2008}} He obtained a work permit at age 13. ==World War I== In August 1914, aged 16, shortly after the outbreak of [[World War I]], Ponticelli was assigned to the [[4th Marching Regiment of the 1st Foreign Regiment]] of the [[French Foreign Legion]]. He had lied about his age to enlist. He rediscovered his older brother, Céleste Ponticelli, who had joined the same regiment. According to Ponticelli, France had done much for him, and serving was his way of showing his gratitude. He served at [[Soissons]] in Picardy, northeast France, and at [[Douaumont]], near [[Verdun]].{{cite news|date=14 March 2008|title=Lazare Ponticelli, 110; France's last surviving World War I veteran|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/mar/14/local/me-ponticelli14|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=17 March 2008}} Ponticelli worked at digging burial pits and trenches.{{cite news|title=Last French World War I Veteran Dies at 110|url=http://www.nysun.com/national/last-french-world-war-i-veteran-dies-at-110/72831/|agency=Associated Press|work=[[The New York Sun]]|date=13 March 2008|accessdate=19 March 2008}} In keeping a promise to Céleste to always assist others, he rescued a German and a French soldier who were wounded in the arm and leg, respectively.{{cite news|url=http://www.metrofrance.com/fr/article/2007/11/11/08/3743-38|title=Un Poilu témoigne|date=11 November 2007|work=Metro France|accessdate=10 December 2008}} Ponticelli was not a French citizen and in May 1915, when Italy entered the war, he was conscripted into the [[Italian Army]]. Although he attempted to remain with his French regiment, he eventually enlisted in the [[3rd Alpini Regiment|3rd Alpini]] Regiment, after being escorted to [[Turin]] by two [[National Gendarmerie|gendarmes]]. Ponticelli saw service against the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]] at Mount Piccolo on the Austria–Italy border. At his new post as a machine gunner, Ponticelli was seriously wounded by a shell during an assault on an Austrian mountain position. He was returned to his post after rest and recuperation in [[Naples]]. In an undated interview, he described being injured: "''Blood was running into my eyes... I continued firing despite my wound."'' Once, his regiment ceased fighting the Austrians for three weeks. The armies, who mostly spoke each other's tongue, swapped loaves of bread for tobacco and photographed each other.{{cite news|date=19 March 2008|title=Lazare Ponticelli|url=http://www.economist.com/obituary/displaystory.cfm?story_id=10875719|work=The Economist|accessdate=9 April 2008}} In 1918 Ponticelli was gassed in an Austrian attack that killed hundreds of his fellow soldiers. Reflecting on war, he said: ''"You shoot at men who are fathers. War is completely stupid."'' In one of his last interviews, Ponticelli stated he was amazed at his own survival.{{cite news|first=Lisa|last=Millar|date=18 March 2008|title=France honours last WWI veteran|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/03/18/2193155.htm|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=24 March 2008}} ==Ponticelli Frères== [[File:Ponticelli bros.jpg|thumb|right|The "Ponticelli Brothers".]] After being demobilized in 1920, Ponticelli founded a metal work company with Céleste and Bonfils, his youngest brother, which they called "Ponticelli Frères" ("Ponticelli Brothers"). Located in the [[13th arrondissement of Paris]], it became profitable and well known in its field. It was incorporated as a private limited company in 1932, when its primary work was with industrial chimneys.{{cite web|url=http://www.ponticelli.com/UK/historique.htm|title=History|year=2002|work=Ponticelli Frères|accessdate=12 December 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060324184050/http://www.ponticelli.com/UK/historique.htm|archivedate=24 March 2006|deadurl=yes}} During the [[Second World War]], Ponticelli, who became a French citizen in 1939, was too old for combat but supported the war effort by supplying soldiers with his products. He moved his factory into an unoccupied zone when Germany invaded and occupied France. After [[Vichy France]] was taken over by the Germans, he returned northwards and began working with the [[French Resistance|Resistance]]. In the aftermath of World War II, he added a piping department to his company. He continued managing the company until his retirement in 1960. At the time of his death it was reported that the company had 4,000 employees and its annual revenue (2005) was €300 million. The company now operates in several countries outside France, such as Angola.{{cite news|url=http://www.avmaroc.com/dossiers/lazare-derniers-a2705.html|title=Lazare, l'un des derniers poilus, "porte le souvenir" de ses camarades|date=11 November 2006|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Dossiers News|language=French|accessdate=10 December 2008}} ==Later life== [[File:Lazare Ponticelli 2006.jpg|thumb|left|Lazare Ponticelli (center) between two reenactment members in old uniforms in 2006]] Until his death, Ponticelli lived with his daughter in the Paris suburb of [[Le Kremlin-Bicêtre]], and every 11 November until 2007 he attended [[Armistice Day]] ceremonies. An honored citizen of his adopted town, Ponticelli voted in the [[French presidential election, 2007|2007 presidential]] and [[French legislative election, 2007|legislative elections]]. He officially became a [[supercentenarian]] on 24 December 2007, celebrating his official 110th birthday at the National History of Immigration Museum.{{cite news|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:NewsBank:TLWB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=11DAA565D706B6E0&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0D0CB579A3BDA420|title=WWI veteran turns 110|date=17 December 2007|work=[[Tulsa World]]|publisher=[[NewsBank]]|page=A6|accessdate=9 December 2008}} He kept his war medals in a shoebox. When originally offered a state funeral by then French President [[Jacques Chirac]], Ponticelli asserted that he did not want one, although the death of the penultimate recognized soldier,{{Ref|art6|[b]}} [[Louis de Cazenave]], on 20 January 2008{{cite news|title=France's oldest WW1 veteran dies|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7199127.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=20 January 2008|accessdate=20 January 2008}} caused him to reconsider. He eventually accepted a small ceremony "in the name of all those who died, men and women," during World War I. {{quote box|width=300px|margin=15px|align=right|qalign=right|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote=Today, I express the nation's deep emotion and infinite sadness. I salute the Italian boy who came to Paris to earn his living and chose to become French, first in August 1914 when he lied about his age to sign up at 16 for the French Foreign Legion to defend his adopted homeland. Then a second time in 1921, when he decided to remain here for good.|source = — Nicolas Sarkozy, President of France}} ==Death== Ponticelli died at 12:45 pm (11:45 GMT) at his home in Le Kremlin-Bicêtre on 12 March 2008, aged 110. At the time of his death, Ponticelli was the oldest living man of Italian birth and the oldest man living in France.{{cite news|title=France's oldest man dies|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/frances-oldest-man-dies/2008/01/21/1200764148295.html|agency=Reuters|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=21 January 2008|accessdate=30 March 2008}} [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], the [[President of France|French president]], released a statement and said there would be a day of national remembrance for the war dead of France. Ponticelli was survived by at least one child, his then-78-year-old daughter, Janine Desbaucheron. His state funeral was held on 17 March 2008. The mass was held at Saint-Louis Cathedral in [[Les Invalides]] and was attended by government ministers, soldiers and members of Ponticelli's family.{{cite news|first=Elaine|last=Ganley|title=Adieu to an oldest soldier|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]|date=18 March 2008}} French academic [[Max Gallo]] delivered the eulogy.{{cite news|title=L'hommage à Ponticelli honore tous les poilus|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/actualites/2008/03/17/01001-20080317ARTFIG00055-l-hommage-a-ponticelli-honore-tous-les-poilus.php|work=Le Figaro|date=16 March 2008|language=French|accessdate=30 March 2008}} At the mass, French ''[[Collège|collégien]]'' Guillaume Kaleff read a poem written by his class in Ponticelli's honor.{{cite news|title=A travers Ponticelli, le vibrant hommage aux Poilus|last=Dagneaux|first=Philippe|date=18 March 2008|work=[[Midi Libre]]|quote="C'est grâce à vous, à tous les Poilus que nous vivons aujourd'hui dans un pays libre. Merci" a dit Guillaume, un élève de cinquième, dans un poème lu en fin de cérémonie.}} Flags were ordered to be flown at half mast while Sarkozy unveiled a plaque dedicated to the veterans of World War I. Legionnaires of the [[3rd Foreign Infantry Regiment]], heir to the [[Marching Regiment of the Foreign Legion|Marching Regiment]] of the French Foreign Legion, the same regiment that Ponticelli fought in, carried his coffin at the funeral. After the procession, he was buried in his family's plot at the Ivry-sur-Seine cemetery, located in the [[Val-de-Marne]].{{cite news|url=http://www.webinfrance.com/last-french-wwi-soldier-dies-110-ending-era-in-france-europe-318.html|title=Last French WWI soldier dies at 110, ending era in France and Europe|date=17 March 2008|work=Web in France Magazine|accessdate=12 December 2008}} ==Legacy== On 11 November 2008, during the first Armistice Day since his death, Rue de Verdun in Le Kremlin-Bicêtre was renamed Rue de Verdun-Lazare-Ponticelli.{{cite news|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/val-de-marne-94/une-rue-baptisee-lazare-ponticelli-12-11-2008-307571.php|title=Une rue baptisée Lazare-Ponticelli|last=Gaudfrin|first=Samantha|date=12 November 2008|work=Le Parisien |language=French|accessdate=9 December 2008}} ==See also== {{Portal|World War I}} * [[List of last surviving World War I veterans by country]] * [[Marching Regiment of the Foreign Legion]] ==Footnotes== {{notelist}} ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' * {{Cite book|title=Ponticelli Frères: les premières années : trois frères, une entreprise|last=Ponticelli|first=Lazare|year=2005|location=Le Kremlin-Bicêtre|isbn=2-9525364-0-6|pages=177 p. with 12 p. of illustrations}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ponticelli, Lazare}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:People from the Province of Piacenza]] [[Category:Recipients of the Croix de guerre (France)]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:French military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:French people of Italian descent]] [[Category:French supercentenarians]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to France]] [[Category:Italian military personnel of World War I]] [[Category:Italian supercentenarians]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Soldiers of the French Foreign Legion]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of Vittorio Veneto]]
